TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit EventHubBufferedProducerClient extends System.Object implements class System.IAsyncDisposable

Docs.summary:
A client responsible for publishing instances of to a specific Event Hub. Depending on the options specified when events are enqueued, they may be automatically assigned to a partition, grouped according to the specified partition key, or assigned a specifically requested partition.
The does not publish immediately, instead using a deferred model where events are collected into a buffer so that they may be efficiently batched and published when the batch is full or the has elapsed with no new events enqueued.
This model is intended to shift the burden of batch management from callers, at the cost of non-deterministic timing, for when events will be published. There are additional trade-offs to consider, as well:
If the application crashes, events in the buffer will not have been published. To prevent data loss, callers are encouraged to track publishing progress using the and handlers.
Events specifying a partition key may be assigned a different partition than those using the same key with other producers.
In the unlikely event that a partition becomes temporarily unavailable, the may take longer to recover than other producers.
In scenarios where it is important to have events published immediately with a deterministic outcome, ensure that partition keys are assigned to a partition consistent with other publishers, or where maximizing availability is a requirement, using the is recommended.
Docs.remarks: The is safe to cache and use as a singleton for the lifetime of an application, which is the recommended approach. The producer is responsible for ensuring efficient network, CPU, and memory use. Calling either or when no more events will be enqueued or as the application is shutting down is required so that the buffer can be flushed and resources cleaned up properly.

MemberSignature.Value: public EventHubBufferedProducerClient (string connectionString);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string connectionString) cil managed
Public Sub New (connectionString As String)
new Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient : string -> Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient

Docs.param: The connection string to use for connecting to the Event Hubs namespace; it is expected that the Event Hub name and the shared key properties are contained in this connection string.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Docs.remarks:
If the connection string is copied from the Event Hubs namespace, it will likely not contain the name of the desired Event Hub, which is needed. In this case, the name can be added manually by adding ";EntityPath=[[ EVENT HUB NAME ]]" to the end of the connection string. For example, ";EntityPath=telemetry-hub".
If you have defined a shared access policy directly on the Event Hub itself, then copying the connection string from that Event Hub will result in a connection string that contains the name.

Public Overridable Function DisposeAsync () As ValueTask

Docs.summary: Closes the producer and performs the tasks needed to clean up all the resources used by the .
Docs.returns: A task to be resolved on when the operation has completed.
Docs.remarks:
Calling this method will also invoke , which will attempt to publish any events that are still pending, and finish any active sending. It will also automatically unregister the and handlers.
This method is identical to and either can be used to send pending events and clean up resources.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.Threading.Tasks.Task<int> EnqueueEventAsync (Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData eventData, System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken = default);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1<int32> EnqueueEventAsync(class Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData eventData, valuetype System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken) cil managed
Public Overridable Function EnqueueEventAsync (eventData As EventData, Optional cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Integer)

abstract member EnqueueEventAsync : Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData * System.Threading.CancellationToken -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<int> override this.EnqueueEventAsync : Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData * System.Threading.CancellationToken -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<int>

Docs.param: The event to be enqueued into the buffer and, later, published.
An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.
Docs.summary:
Enqueues an into the buffer to be published to the Event Hub. If there is no capacity in the buffer when this method is invoked, it will wait for space to become available and ensure that the has been enqueued.
When this call returns, the has been accepted into the buffer, but it may not have been published yet. Publishing will take place at a nondeterministic point in the future as the buffer is processed.
Docs.returns: The total number of events that are currently buffered and waiting to be published, across all partitions.
Docs.remarks: Upon the first attempt to enqueue an event, the and handlers can no longer be changed.
Docs.exception: Occurs when no handler is currently registered.

Enqueues an into the buffer to be published to the Event Hub. If there is no capacity in the buffer when this method is invoked, it will wait for space to become available and ensure that the has been enqueued.
When this call returns, the has been accepted into the buffer, but it may not have been published yet. Publishing will take place at a nondeterministic point in the future as the buffer is processed.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.Threading.Tasks.Task<int> EnqueueEventsAsync (System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData> events, System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken = default);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1<int32> EnqueueEventsAsync(class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData> events, valuetype System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken) cil managed
Public Overridable Function EnqueueEventsAsync (events As IEnumerable(Of EventData), Optional cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Integer)

abstract member EnqueueEventsAsync : seq<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData> * System.Threading.CancellationToken -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<int> override this.EnqueueEventsAsync : seq<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData> * System.Threading.CancellationToken -> System.Threading.Tasks.Task<int>

Docs.param: The set of events to be enqueued into the buffer and, later, published.
An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.
Docs.summary:
Enqueues a set of into the buffer to be published to the Event Hub. If there is insufficient capacity in the buffer when this method is invoked, it will wait for space to become available and ensure that all in the set have been enqueued.
When this call returns, the have been accepted into the buffer, but it may not have been published yet. Publishing will take place at a nondeterministic point in the future as the buffer is processed.
Docs.returns: The total number of events that are currently buffered and waiting to be published, across all partitions.
Docs.remarks:
Should cancellation or an unexpected exception occur, it is possible for calls to this method to result in a partial failure where some, but not all, of the have enqueued. For scenarios where it is important to understand whether each individual event has been enqueued, it is recommended to call the see or overloads instead of this method.
Upon the first attempt to enqueue events, the and handlers can no longer be changed.
Docs.exception: Occurs when no handler is currently registered.

When this call returns, the have been accepted into the buffer, but it may not have been published yet. Publishing will take place at a nondeterministic point in the future as the buffer is processed.

Docs.remarks:
Should cancellation or an unexpected exception occur, it is possible for calls to this method to result in a partial failure where some, but not all, of the have enqueued. For scenarios where it is important to understand whether each individual event has been enqueued, it is recommended to call the see or overloads instead of this method.

Docs.summary:
Attempts to publish all events in the buffer immediately. This may result in multiple batches being published, the outcome of each of which will be individually reported by the and handlers.
Upon completion of this method, the buffer will be empty.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool IsPublishing { get; }
.property instance bool IsPublishing
Public Overridable ReadOnly Property IsPublishing As Boolean
member this.IsPublishing : bool

Docs.summary: Indicates whether or not this is currently active and publishing queued events.
Docs.value: true if the client is publishing; otherwise, false.
Docs.remarks:
The producer will begin publishing when an event is enqueued and should remain active until either or is called.
If any events were enqueued, is false, and is false, this likely indicates an unrecoverable state for the client. It is recommended to close the and create a new instance.
In this state, exceptions will be reported by the Event Hubs client library logs, which can be captured using the .

MemberSignature.Value: public event Func<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventBatchFailedEventArgs,System.Threading.Tasks.Task> SendEventBatchFailedAsync;
.event class System.Func`2<class Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventBatchFailedEventArgs, class System.Threading.Tasks.Task> SendEventBatchFailedAsync
Public Custom Event SendEventBatchFailedAsync As Func(Of SendEventBatchFailedEventArgs, Task)
member this.SendEventBatchFailedAsync : Func<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventBatchFailedEventArgs, System.Threading.Tasks.Task>

Docs.summary:
Invoked for any batch of events that failed to be published to the Event Hub, this handler must be provided before events may be enqueued. If this producer was not configured with and both set to 1, the handler will be invoked concurrently.
It is safe to attempt resending the events by calling or from within this handler. It is important to note that doing so will place them at the end of the buffer; the original order will not be maintained.
This handler will be awaited after failure to publish the batch; the publishing operation is not considered complete until the handler call returns. It is advised that no long-running operations be performed in the handler to avoid negatively impacting throughput.
It is not recommended to invoke or from this handler; doing so may result in a deadlock scenario if those calls are awaited.
Docs.remarks:
Should a transient failure occur during publishing, this handler will not be invoked immediately; it is only invoked after applying the retry policy and all eligible retries have been exhausted. Should publishing succeed during a retry attempt, this handler is not invoked.
Since applications do not have deterministic control over failed batches, it is recommended that the application set a generous number of retries and try timeout interval in the . Doing so will allow the a higher chance to recover from transient failures. This is especially important when ensuring the order of events is needed.
It is not necessary to explicitly unregister this handler; it will be automatically unregistered when or is invoked.
Docs.exception: If an attempt is made to remove a handler that doesn't match the current handler registered.
If an attempt is made to add a handler when one is currently registered.

MemberSignature.Value: public event Func<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventBatchSucceededEventArgs,System.Threading.Tasks.Task> SendEventBatchSucceededAsync;
.event class System.Func`2<class Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventBatchSucceededEventArgs, class System.Threading.Tasks.Task> SendEventBatchSucceededAsync
Public Custom Event SendEventBatchSucceededAsync As Func(Of SendEventBatchSucceededEventArgs, Task)
member this.SendEventBatchSucceededAsync : Func<Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventBatchSucceededEventArgs, System.Threading.Tasks.Task>

Docs.summary:
Invoked after each batch of events has been successfully published to the Event Hub, this handler is optional and is intended to provide notifications for interested listeners. If this producer was configured with or set greater than 1, the handler will be invoked concurrently.
This handler will be awaited after publishing the batch; the publishing operation will not be considered complete until the handler call returns. It is advised that no long-running operations be performed in the handler to avoid negatively impacting throughput.
It is not recommended to invoke or from this handler; doing so may result in a deadlock scenario if those calls are awaited.
Docs.remarks: It is not necessary to explicitly unregister this handler; it will be automatically unregistered when or is invoked.
Docs.exception: If an attempt is made to remove a handler that doesn't match the current handler registered.
If an attempt is made to add a handler when one is currently registered.
